title: Extra space in some Vue-generated links
description:
### Problem to solve

In certain Vue-generated links there is a trailing space.

### Proposal

Links should not have a trailing space.

### Example

The example below appears on [all GitLab issue pages](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/).  It is not clear why, as [the Vue file does not show a space there](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/app/assets/javascripts/design_management/pages/index.vue#L336).

title: Handle situations where the user switches between content formats
description:
## Goal

When switching between **Content Editor** format and other formats (like Markdown, Rdoc) must caution the user about compatibility issues.

- [ ] If the content of the page is empty, switching format should not caution/show a message to the user.
- [ ] If the page has some content, regardless of whether editing an existing page or creating a new page, switching between formats might not be the best thing to do, so we should show a warning to the user about incompatibility.

title: Add Content Editor as an option when creating or editing a Wiki Page
description:
## Goal

- A button titled "Use new editor" is visible when the feature when the feature flag `wiki_content_editor` is turned on and markdown format is selected. 
- Clicking on the button should show the content editor instead of the markdown editor. 
- A warning should appear telling people that the content editor is in beta. A button "switch to old editor" should be a part of the warning that switches content back to the old editor.
- Switching formats should not be allowed when in the new editor. You can switch formats only when you go back to the old editor.
- When switching back to the old editor, the content in the old editor should be restored (discarding any changes in the new editor).
- When in the old editor, the format dropdown is enabled again and the user can switch between the formats again.

![image](/uploads/021b63e15bc21a13a22ceb320bb1d812/image.png)

title: Allow ability to disable pipelines for merge requests from running in target projects via project settings
description:
GitLab released a feature in 13.3 which allows some pipelines from merge requests to run in the context of the target project [1]. However, it might be the case that even internal contributors (those that have the "Developer" role or higher on the target project) might want to run pipelines in the context of the source project, not the target project. In this case, all engineers' pipelines (regardless of role) will run with the same context: the source project's context.

Adding the ability to turn this feature off via a project-specific configuration would support this.

[1] https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/ci/merge_request_pipelines/#run-pipelines-in-the-parent-project-for-merge-requests-from-a-forked-project

title: Geo Status Page 2.0 - UI Backstage Followups
description:
## What/Why This issue is to track the varying reviews throughout the MR split out that causes some of the technical implementations of the predecessor MRs to get out of sync. This issue will track all the ~javascript follow ups to keep the code style consistent throughout this scope `geo_nodes_beta`. ## Implementation
Category Feedback MR
Test Optimization 1. Remove `wrapper = null` usages: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/55546#note_526492295
2. Use `findComponent` in all spec files: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/55904#note_529228489
3. Use `findByTestId` in all spec files: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/55904#note_529228491
4. Use kebab-case for `data-testid`: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/55546#note_526492274
5. Don't use negation for the `does/does not` render specs: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/55904#note_531695094
6. Remove `toBeTruthy()` usage: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/55695#note_534357564 		https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/60167
i18n 1. Use `$options.i18n` for all template translations: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/55546#note_526492283
2. Use `$options.i18n` for all script translations: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/56154#note_538534351
3. Scope Geo translations to `s__('Geo|...')`: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/54857#note_518990929 		https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/60163
helpPagePath 1. Use `helpPagePath` to build `constants.js` urls: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/54857#note_518990921
2. Use `anchor` property on `helpPagePath` where applicable: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/55695#note_534353020 		https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/60164
Vuex in Specs 1. Remove `localVue` from specs: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/55904#note_531695081
2. Remove `Vuex.Store` from specs that do not need it: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/55904#note_531695081 		https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/60151
GitLab UI 1. Remove `"tabindex=0"` from `GlIcon` popovers as it is not needed to trigger the focus event: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/55695#note_534351480
2. Adjust popover text sizes to `gl-font-base`: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/55695#note_534352570
3. Use `GlSprintf` for inline translations w/ links: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/55695#note_534352570
4. Stub `GlCard` instead of `mount`: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/56412#note_542439436 		https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/60421
Time Ago 1. Use `time-ago` component instead of mixin: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/56154#note_538534363 https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/60434

title: Dark mode: User settings dropdowns have white background
description:
### Summary The dropdowns on the user settings pages are showing with a white background (both when closed and when opened) when the dark mode theme is activated. This should ideally be changed to be a different (darker color). Note that the text fields are a nice dark color on the page. ### Steps to reproduce Enable the dark mode theme. Go to the user preferences page and then go to any settings page with dropdowns (e.g. Notifications, Preferences). ### Example Project ### What is the current *bug* behavior? The dropdowns appear with a white background, as shown in this screenshot: ![image](/uploads/453d023388a8ef24ef41fe63189c7986/image.png) ### What is the expected *correct* behavior? The color of the dropdowns should be darker (like the text entry fields or the dropdowns on the new issue page) when the dark mode theme is enabled. Dropdowns on the New Issue page that look correct: ![image](/uploads/fe363d9730df321ec162a440fcfdac14/image.png) ### Relevant logs and/or screenshots ### Output of checks This bug happens on GitLab.com #### Results of GitLab environment info N/A #### Results of GitLab application Check
Expand for output related to the GitLab application check 

(For installations with omnibus-gitlab package run and paste the output of:
`sudo gitlab-rake gitlab:check SANITIZE=true`)

(For installations from source run and paste the output of:
`sudo -u git -H bundle exec rake gitlab:check RAILS_ENV=production SANITIZE=true`)

(we will only investigate if the tests are passing)
### Possible fixes

title: `UserCallout` Mutation and Query
description: We need a GraphQL Mutation for the `UserCallout` endpoint and the value available in the pipeline and pipeline editor queries so we can track when a user has dismissed a callout.

title: Enhance controls on permitted SSH keys to take FIPS requirements into account
description:
### Proposal 

GitLab includes support for placing restrictions on types and strengths of SSH keys used by clients: https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/security/ssh_keys_restrictions.html#restrict-allowed-ssh-key-technologies-and-minimum-length

Only some of the possible configurations are FIPS-compliant, e.g. DSA keys are absolutely not supported under FIPS.

The OpenSSH server (or gitlab-sshd) can be configured to reject forbidden keys at that level, but we should probably also have a "FIPS mode" for this configuration that enables only those keys and strengths that are permitted. This will give users better feedback (adding the keys to the instance will be forbidden), and remove a dependency on an external component when it comes to enforcing compliance.

title: [Engineering] Update null_hypothesis as "Canary Experiment" and Tests to Alert us to Breaking Changes
description:
# Overview 

In order to identify changes that could impact our experimentation and its data, we want to create an experiment that runs in perpetuity, with no impact to the user experience (E.g. a null hypothesis test) that can serve as a "canary in the cole mine" to alert us to changes that could negatively impact the reliability of data from experiments. 

# Next Steps 

- [x] Identify/create an experiment to use 
- [x] Create tests around it 
- [ ] Create monitoring around it (if necessary)

title: Use `.safe_find_or_create_by`  in package managers services
description:
Follow up of: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/34558#note_531005335

### :fire: Problem

In package manager services, we're often in the situation where we need:
1. check if a package record exists
1. if that's not the case, create a new one

Those steps are usually done in two different statements. This can lead to race conditions where two process try to do (1.) and (2.) at the same time which can lead to a failure of (2.) with `RecordNotUnique`.

### :fire_engine: Solution

Use [`.safe_find_or_create_by`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/d96bcdf74001205ffeb7d830e006c06d99c26c5d/app/models/application_record.rb#L49) which basically do both steps in a safer way.

All package types APIs must be inspected. In particular, [maven](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/f888c76617936208413d2c17351c72a6f58456c9/app/services/packages/maven/find_or_create_package_service.rb#L8-50) service should be updated.

title: Present Lead time for MRs to be deployed to production in group level CI/CD dashboard - Ultimate
description:
<!-- The first section "Release notes" is required if you want to have your release post blog MR auto generated. Currently piloting, details can be found in this issue: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-com/Product/-/issues/1392 and this video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rfn9ebgTwKg The next four sections: "Problem to solve", "Intended users", "User experience goal", and "Proposal", are strongly recommended in your first draft, while the rest of the sections can be filled out during the problem validation or breakdown phase. However, keep in mind that providing complete and relevant information early helps our product team validate the problem and start working on a solution. -->

### Release notes 

<!-- What is the problem and solution you're proposing? This content sets the overall vision for the feature and serves as the release notes that will populate in various places, including the [release post blog](https://about.gitlab.com/releases/categories/releases/) and [Gitlab project releases](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/releases). " -->

### Problem to solve

<!-- What problem do we solve? Try to define the who/what/why of the opportunity as a user story. For example, "As a (who), I want (what), so I can (why/value)." -->

As an executive investing in DevOps, I want to see my ROI. I want to see an improvement in the lead time for changes of my dev team. This will most likely drive the KPIs of my team.

As a developer leader I want to see that the team is improving by measuring the lead for changes and comparing it over time (over sprints)

### Intended users

<!-- Who will use this feature? If known, include any of the following: types of users (e.g. Developer), personas, or specific company roles (e.g. Release Manager). It's okay to write "Unknown" and fill this field in later.

Personas are described at https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/

* [Cameron (Compliance Manager)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#cameron-compliance-manager)
* [Parker (Product Manager)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#parker-product-manager)
* [Delaney (Development Team Lead)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#delaney-development-team-lead)
* [Presley (Product Designer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#presley-product-designer)
* [Sasha (Software Developer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sasha-software-developer)
* [Devon (DevOps Engineer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#devon-devops-engineer)
* [Sidney (Systems Administrator)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sidney-systems-administrator)
* [Sam (Security Analyst)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sam-security-analyst)
* [Rachel (Release Manager)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#rachel-release-manager) 
* [Alex (Security Operations Engineer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#alex-security-operations-engineer)
* [Simone (Software Engineer in Test)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#simone-software-engineer-in-test)
* [Allison (Application Ops)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#allison-application-ops) 
* [Priyanka (Platform Engineer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#priyanka-platform-engineer)
* [Dana (Data Analyst)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#dana-data-analyst)
-->

* [Parker (Product Manager)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#parker-product-manager)
* [Delaney (Development Team Lead)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#delaney-development-team-lead)
* [Rachel (Release Manager)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#rachel-release-manager) 

### User experience goal

<!-- What is the single user experience workflow this problem addresses? 
For example, "The user should be able to use the UI/API/.gitlab-ci.yml with GitLab to <perform a specific task>"
https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/ux/ux-research-training/user-story-mapping/ --> 

Today we show https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/value_stream_analytics

![image](/uploads/8ea3826e231c8dd3819838876ffca343/image.png)

We already present number of commits as a numerical value under value stream analytics, we should show number of MRs as well, but we should show this in a chart view - as the trend is the most interesting aspect of this metric. 




### Proposal

<!-- How are we going to solve the problem? Try to include the user journey! https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/journeys/#user-journey -->

Based on [Group Level API support for Deployment Frequency](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/291747), we will present the **median** time it takes from when an MR is ready until it is merged into production (this does not include coding time) - this will accumulate the data from all the projects in the group and present the median based on that.

Days with zero deployments we will not show a period in the graph.

 Graph visualization (which will happen in %"13.11") would need a bit more UX input due to the opposite evaluation method than deployment frequencies.

You can check the recording of the async call below.

* Recording: https://youtu.be/NDwdGS3Q5E0
* GDoc: https://docs.google.com/document/d/1SAEFOslL6chD6_bZf7XYNZebJP-6qmj_EMR6lOzjkcY/edit?usp=sharing

![image](/uploads/842d5e074fdbc6c2335547055664b2a7/image.png)

Note: “View Data by [Day/Week]” dropdown will be implemented separately in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/326535

<details>
  <summary>
    💎 Expand full design proposal
  </summary>

---

- [Based on our design system docs](https://design.gitlab.com/data-visualization/charts/?path=%2Fstory%2Fcharts-chart--default#line-charts), using a line chart for time-series data like this is the right choice
- We want to convey that periods with no MRs deployed have **no MTTM data available**, rather than **0 minutes of MTTM**
- Depending on front-end limitations we might not be able to implement this exact design, but it's is a good starting point for this MVC

| Option | Screenshot | Notes |
| ------ | ------ | ------ |
| 1 | ![mttm-1](/uploads/f1a3c615323ba2a3f5434282879e041a/mttm-1.png) | Clearly marks and labels periods with no data for users. **This is the version that will be developed** |
| 2 | ![mttm-2](/uploads/56b25df77e8672f579c15376df1b3738/mttm-2.png) | Subtler version with less focus on "no data" periods |
| 3 | ![mttm-3](/uploads/9be5d4d008952f4f5b4375a876ef7208/mttm-3.png) | Even simpler version that does not render anything for periods with no data (would be unable to open tooltip here without a visual target) |

##### Chart in page context

We could also provide a toggled off option that entirely hides "no data" periods to show a seamless progression of MTTM. Note that even the dates are cut off from the chart here.

![image](/uploads/500f9e94dd00f061b4140ca8eb7160b7/image.png)

Page loads with toggle ON by default:

![image](/uploads/49b2ec5cb8a066adb611117a5fefc211/image.png)

</details>


### Further details

<!-- Include use cases, benefits, goals, or any other details that will help us understand the problem better. -->

<strike>* Lead time for changes - how long does it take for code to be committed and reach production


What this looks like in Cloudbees 

![image](/uploads/0320f6723f45d185b4b2bb46ecbfdf55/image.png)


What this looks like in Atlassian

![image](/uploads/7c3ffd40a2601cf4e96c33e0c76c3d8d/image.png)

<!-- What permissions are required to perform the described actions? Are they consistent with the existing permissions as documented for users, groups, and projects as appropriate? Is the proposed behavior consistent between the UI, API, and other access methods (e.g. email replies)?

title: Roll out swimlanes_buffered_rendering feature
description:
<!-- Title suggestion: [Feature flag] Enable description of feature -->

## What

Remove the `:swimlanes_buffered_rendering` feature flag.

Introduced: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/324736

## Owners

- Team: Plan
- Most appropriate slack channel to reach out to: `#s_plan`
- Best individual to reach out to: `@fguibert`

## Expectations

### What are we expecting to happen?

Improves rendering of lanes for Epics Swimlanes.

### What might happen if this goes wrong?

Issues rendering Epics Swimlanes.

## Beta groups/projects

If applicable, any groups/projects that are happy to have this feature turned on early. Some organizations may wish to test big changes they are interested in with a small subset of users ahead of time for example.

- `gitlab-org/gitlab` project
- `gitlab-org`/`gitlab-com` groups

## Roll Out Steps

- [ ] Enable on staging (`/chatops run feature set swimlanes_buffered_rendering true --staging`)
- [ ] Test on staging
- [ ] Ensure that documentation has been updated
- [ ] Enable on GitLab.com for individual groups/projects listed above and verify behaviour  (`/chatops run feature set --project=gitlab-org/gitlab swimlanes_buffered_rendering true`)
- [ ] Coordinate a time to enable the flag with the SRE oncall and release managers
  - In `#production` mention `@sre-oncall` and `@release-managers`. Once an SRE on call and Release Manager on call confirm, you can proceed with the rollout
- [ ] Announce on the issue an estimated time this will be enabled on GitLab.com
- [ ] Enable on GitLab.com by running chatops command in `#production` (`/chatops run feature set feature_name true`)
- [ ] Cross post chatops Slack command to `#support_gitlab-com` ([more guidance when this is necessary in the dev docs](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#where-to-run-commands)) and in your team channel
- [ ] Announce on the issue that the flag has been enabled
- [ ] Remove feature flag and add changelog entry. Ensure that the feature flag definition YAML file has been removed in the **same MR** that is removing the feature flag from the code
- [ ] After the flag removal is deployed, [clean up the feature flag](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#cleaning-up) by running chatops command in `#production` channel

## Rollback Steps

- [ ] This feature can be disabled by running the following Chatops command:

```
/chatops run feature set --project=gitlab-org/gitlab swimlanes_buffered_rendering false
```

title: DAST On-Demand: Move DAST site validation to runner
description:
### Problem to Solve
When a user saves a url, the built-in url validation prohibits the saving of any url that resolves to a non-routable address as documented by users, https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/270751. This is done as a security measure so that the monolith does not access a non-routable url. 

### Solution
1) Move the domain validation work to a runner. By moving the validation to a runner, the runner can validate a domain regardless of whether that domain resolves to an internal ip or an external ip. 

2) Once the domain validation is done exclusively on the runner, and monolith/sidekiq no longer visit domains from their trusted servers, the domain validation should be removed from the model. 

The validation error exposed in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/270751, will auto-resolve.

## Implementation

- [x] Add feature flag (`:dast_runner_site_validation`) https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/61649
- [x] Add internal API https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/61649
- [x] Add container for validation https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/dast-runner-validation/-/merge_requests/1
- [x] Release container https://gitlab.com/security-products/dast-runner-validation/container_registry
- [x] Add validation strategy to the monolith behind feature flag https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/65794
- [x] [Add new `ci_pipelines.source` for validation](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/65794#note_630608078) (e.g. `ondemand_dast_validation`) https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/66991
- [x] Add documentation
- [x] Add support for offline environments by updating Secure-Binaries.gitlab-ci.yml (documentation on how this works https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/application_security/offline_deployments/) https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/66501

title: Hide "New issue" button on group "Issues" page from Auditors
description:
### Summary

"New issue" button/dropdown on group "Issues" page should only be shown to Auditors if there are projects they have access to. If it is shown to Auditors the items in the dropdown should only be the projects they have access to.

### Steps to reproduce

1. Create a group
1. Create a project in that group
1. Log-in as an Auditor
1. Navigate to "Group" -> "Issues"

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

"New issue" button/dropdown is shown to Auditors

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

"New issue" button/dropdown should only be shown to Auditors if there are projects they have write access to. Projects in the dropdown should only be shown if Auditor has write access to them.

### Relevant logs and/or screenshots

![Screen_Shot_2021-03-16_at_2.25.46_PM](/uploads/746ff79558924d1dc41699d0cebad446/Screen_Shot_2021-03-16_at_2.25.46_PM.png)

### Possible fixes

- Add query parameter to [app/assets/javascripts/project_select.js#L64](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/app/assets/javascripts/project_select.js#L64) so API only returns projects with full access.

title: Change Dependency Scanning QA to expect exit code when vulnerabilities are detected
description:
### Problem to solve

The Dependency Scanning jobs are changed so that they exit with a non-zero exit code when vulnerabilities are detected, but currently the integration tests using the Secure test projects and "QA jobs" don't check the exit code.

### Proposal

Change the [CI template used for integration tests of Dependency Scanning](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/ci-templates/-/blob/master/includes-dev/qa-dependency_scanning.yml) to capture and compare the exit code.

Here are two options:
1. override the `script` of the scanning job to capture the exit code, pass it to the corresponding `qa-` job using artifacts, and there compare it to an expected value
1. override the `script` of the scanning job to compare it to the expected code, and fail if it doesn't match

The latter is easier to implement.

The tests should cover both the legacy behavior (exit code `0` when vulnerabilities are found) and the new one (non-zero exit code when vulnerabilities are found).

Additional tests are needed for when no vulnerabilities are found, to make sure that it exits with exit code `0`.

### Other links/references

https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/324634#implementation-plan

title: Support TLS connections for all metrics endpoints in GitLab components
description:
This might be better as a sub-epic of FIPS compliance, with an issue per project that needs modifications.

GitLab components report metrics via Prometheus, and sometimes start a pprof listener to aid live profiling. Either of these may be open and listening when running GitLab in production, as they are on GitLab.com

Here's a list of ones I've spotted so far. It's probably not comprehensive:

* [gitlab-workhorse](workhorse/main.go#L84)
* [gitlab-rails](config/initializers/7_prometheus_metrics.rb)
* [gitlab-sshd](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab-shell/-/blob/main/cmd/gitlab-sshd/main.go#L60)
* [gitlab-pages](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab-pages/-/blob/master/main.go#L161)

Currently, none of these endpoints are capable of being TLS-secured. In a FIPS-compliant setup, I think we *must* TLS-secure them all. This implies taking a key+cert in addition to the listen address.

We also need to get https://github.com/prometheus/common/pull/283 merged, as prometheus uses MD5 internally for one thing.

title: Change Secure analyzers/command library in order to fail when vulnerabilities detected and new exit codes enabled
description:
### Problem to solve 

Secure analyzers implemented in Go need to be be changed so that the `run` command return a non-zero exit code when vulnerabilities are found, but this new behavior shouldn't be enabled by default, to ensure backward compatibility.

### Further details

Most Secure analyzers implemented in Go rely on the [analyzers/command](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/command) Go package to implement the `run` command. Currently this function returns no error when the scan is successful, even if the generated JSON report contains vulnerabilities.

[analyzers/command](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/command) was extracted from [analyzers/common](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/common), and some analyzers still use this other repo.

### Proposal

- Declare a new CLI flag and environment variable, to control the exit codes
- Change the `Run` function so that it returns an error when vulnerabilities are found, depending on the aforementioned environment variable; make the error implement the `ExitCoder` interface of `urfave/cli` to communicate the exit code.
- Fetch the exit code from map, using a constant specific to that scenario
- Define exit code maps that correspond to the existing behavior and the new one
- Switch between the exit code maps/tables based on the environment variable defined in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/324634#proposal

A new Go package named `exitcodes` gathers all the code needed to throw the correct exit code, based on the environment variables. This package is used by the `command` package and by the analyzers that implement their own `run` command.

TBD: Is `exitcodes` a new repo, or is it a sub-package of `command`?

### Implementation plan

- [ ] Create a new `exitcodes` package that contains:
   - CLI flag for the exit codes version
   - constants for the supported error cases, like "vulnerabilities detected"
   - helper functions to resolve constants to errors to be returned, using the CLI context  
- [ ] Update the `run` command in the `command` package
   - include CLI flag exported by `exitcodes`
   - use helper functions and constants exported by `exitcodes` to return the correct exit code when the generated report contains at least one vulnerabilities

### Availability & Testing

This will be tested in the integration tests of the Secure analyzers using the `common` library, when checking the exit code.

### Is this a cross-stage feature?

This is stage-wide.

### Links / references

- implementation plan: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/324634#implementation-plan
- @adamcohen's experiments: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/324634#note_530145822
- @gonzoyumo's proposal: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/324634#note_530604706

title: Show Dependency List when Dependency Scanning jobs failed but allowed to fail
description:
<!-- The first section "Release notes" is required if you want to have your release post blog MR auto generated. Currently in BETA, details on the **release post item generator** can be found in the handbook:  https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/blog/release-posts/#release-post-item-generator and this video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rfn9ebgTwKg. The next four sections: "Problem to solve", "Intended users", "User experience goal", and "Proposal", are strongly recommended in your first draft, while the rest of the sections can be filled out during the problem validation or breakdown phase. However, keep in mind that providing complete and relevant information early helps our product team validate the problem and start working on a solution. -->

:warning: **NOTE:** The proposal needs to be updated based on the outcome of the [conversation](https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/5334#note_537324954) taking place in the [parent epic](https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/5334). :warning: 

### Release notes

Technical change, not needed

### Problem to solve 

Security Scanners are changed so that they return a non-zero exit code when vulnerabilities are found, but in that case the Dependency List shows an error, and dependencies are not listed.

### Proposal

Change the Dependency List page so that it doesn't show an error when the Dependency Scanning jobs (of the latest pipeline for the default branch) fail but are allowed to fail, and return a valid report with dependencies. Instead, it should list dependencies as usual.

### Implementation plan

- [ ] Override the `status` method in the `DependencyListEntity` so that it's `ok` when job failed but allowed to fail

### Further details

See current behavior documented in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/324634#note_530462982

> Currently the `Dependency List` page shows an error message and no dependencies when the last Dependency Scanning jobs  for the default branch have failed. This is true **even if the jobs are allowed to fail.**

![Capture_d_écran_2021-03-16_à_13.44.03](/uploads/68d9a99bb40659b8e0e4bd653762c666/Capture_d_écran_2021-03-16_à_13.44.03.png)

Message is rendered in Vue component [dependency_list_job_failed_alert.vue](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/v13.10.0-ee/ee/app/assets/javascripts/dependencies/components/dependency_list_job_failed_alert.vue#L30), imported in [app.vue](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/v13.10.0-ee/ee/app/assets/javascripts/dependencies/components/app.vue#L8)

The `job_failed` status is set in the [`ReportListEntity`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/v13.10.0-ee/ee/app/serializers/report_list_entity.rb#L42), which is shared between the [`LicensesListEntity`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/v13.10.0-ee/ee/app/serializers/licenses_list_entity.rb#L3) and the [`DependencyListEntity`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/v13.10.0-ee/ee/app/serializers/dependency_list_entity.rb#L3). There are specs for `DependencyListEntity` and `LicensesListEntity`, but not for `ReportListEntity` itself.

### Permissions and Security

No change

### Documentation

No change

### Availability & Testing

We need an additional test case for when scanning jobs are failed AND allowed to fail AND generate a valid Dependency Scanning report: the Dependency List must list the project dependencies along with their vulnerabilities.

### Is this a cross-stage feature?

No, this is specific to ~"group::composition analysis" 

### Links / references

https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/324634#note_530462982

title: [FE] Generic Report Schema: Render list & url types on vulnerability details page
description:
<!--
Implementation issues are used break-up a large piece of work into small, discrete tasks that can
move independently through the build workflow steps. They're typically used to populate a Feature
Epic. Once created, an implementation issue is usually refined in order to populate and review the
implementation plan and weight.
Example workflow: https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/development/threat-management/planning/diagram.html#plan
-->

## Why are we doing this work

Allows scan results to add new labels and values to a vulnerability, where the label is any string they want and the value is one of the following types: `named-list`, `list`, `table`, `url`, `int`, `text`, `diff`, `markdown` (GFM), `code`, `commit`, `file-location`, and `module-location`.

This issue is specific to the following higher priority & more complicated types: `named-list`, `list` & `url`

### Designs

| component | design |
| ------ | ------ |
| **url** | ![Screen_Shot_2021-03-24_at_10.08.14_am](/uploads/14651820ff73958cbb24b4ed0bb1cf6c/Screen_Shot_2021-03-24_at_10.08.14_am.png) |
| ** list** | TBC |

(**Note**: the `list` component is used to recursively render nested arrays of items)

### Sample Data

### url

```json
"details": {
  "site_url": {
    "name": "URL",
    "type": "url",
    "href": "http://site.com"
  }
}
```

### list

Note that a list can contain a list of list of list of list of list.... etc. Personally, I'd recommending setting a limit on the UI, but I'll leave that up to you!

```json
"details": {
  "urls": {
    "name": "URLs",
    "type": "list",
    "items": [
      {
        "type": "url",
        "href": "http://nginx/page/1"
      },
      {
        "type": "url",
        "href": "http://nginx/page/2"
      }
    ]
  }
}
```

<!--
A brief explanation of the why, not the what or how. Assume the reader doesn't know the
background and won't have time to dig-up information from comment threads.
-->

## Relevant links
Information that the developer might need to refer to when implementing the issue.

- [Design Issue](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/267193)
  - [Design 1](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/267193/designs/a2-Vuln-Details-Page_generic-schema-evidence-expandable.png)
- [POC example](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/233168)

title: F/u/f #288015: Iterate on trial status widget popover title
description:
The change would look like this:

| Before | After
|---|---
| ![image](/uploads/7f491274f0aa27201f54fd9e0ebd0c7f/image.png) | ![image](/uploads/bf42dbe5eee4fd1254157a20d951565d/image.png)

The main popover copy has probably already changed a bit, so we’re just focusing on the popover title here.

---

The following discussion from !55894 should be addressed:

- [ ] @kcomoli started a [discussion](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/55894#note_530284912):

    > @dreedy Thanks for the ping! I'm not keen on changing the headline of the popover, here is why:
    >
    > - We are duplicating information. The first piece of information you get with the widget is that you have 5 days left on your trial. Adding an extra "5 days remaining" in the popover headline feels redundant, and overusing scarcity can be perceived as "pushy".
    > - Since we've yet to launch the experiment, we should hold-off on extra scarcity for now. We can always iterate and experiment on copy if we feel it's the way to go (personally I don't, but happy to be proven wrong).
    > - From a learning perspective, it's probably better to start without this piece of copy, then add it and measure its impact. It's also why we started with a simple "Hey there" as a MVC.
    >
    > @s_awezec @aqualls Curious to get your thoughts on the points above.
    >
    > The rest of the copy is fine for me 👍

Which relates to the following discussion from #288015:

- [ ] @aqualls started a [discussion](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/288015#note_510491132) (7+ replies):

    > @kcomoli @dreedy I have some ideas here! Here's the current text:
    >
    > > Hey there! :wave:
    > >
    > > Your trial ends on 2021-03-02. We hope you are enjoying GitLab Gold. To continue using GitLab Gold after your trial ends, you will need to buy a subscription. You can also choose GitLab Premium if its features are sufficient for your needs.
    >
    > I don't know how many of these changes we can make in this iteration, but a couple really jump out at me. Here's an idea:
    > 
    > > You've got 23 day\[s\] remaining on GitLab Gold! :wave:
    > >
    > > Your trial ends on 2021-03-02. We hope you're enjoying the features of GitLab Gold. To keep those features after your trial ends, you'll need to buy a subscription. (You can also choose GitLab Premium if it meets your needs.)
    > 
    > * The "Hey there" line will be the most read line. Let's put our most important information there, but don't do it this way if we can't differentiate between "1 day" and "2 days" because that always makes me :face_palm_tone2: when I see something like "You have 1 days remaining."
    > * Can we translate dates into friendlier language? (I don't know how much work this entails.) There's no single date format that will make everyone happy, but in this case, the timeline is so short that the year is implied. Maybe "March 2" instead of 2021-03-02?
    > * Hammer home features, features, features. What the user gets in GitLab Gold are features. (Could we link to them too?)
    > * +1 to the "meets your needs" instead of "sufficient"
    > 
    > Thoughts? As always, steal what works for you and discard the rest.

title: Return `content` in the `CreateCommit` mutation
description:
In order to have better error handling and remove some technical debt from the frontend, there is a requirement to return the content in the `CreateCommit` mutation.

title: Make it easy to share a filtered view of the registry
description:
### Release post

You use the GitLab Package and Container Registry to publish and share your project's dependencies. You use the user interface to view, validate and (sometimes) troubleshoot those dependencies. But have you ever found yourself filtering the registry based on name or type and then tried to share a link with your teammate? You can't do it. That means that your teammate had to manually search/filter the registry to recreate the same view as you. This is quite inefficient and could result in someone using the wrong dependency. 

Moving forward, you will be able to share a link to these views to help make sharing and discovering the dependencies of your project seamless. This is part of a larger epic to improve dependency search, discovery and deletion. You can follow that epic here: https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/5152


### Problem to solve

Currently, the `Registries` have a searching and filtering UI that is totally similar to Issue and MR searches.

The difference results in the fact that the search and sorting terms are not reflected in the URL thus making the search/sorting configuration not linkable.

### Proposal

Connect those to the URL and allow users to share links of `pre filtered` registries.

title: Workhorse: Stop using MD5 hashing for uploads to S3
description:
Workhorse is responsible for uploading files to object storage. We support lots of different stores, and various categories of files can be uploaded, but a particular combination is LFS objects stored in Amazon S3.

There are two different ways to configure uploads in this case, and both use MD5 checksums to verify data integrity - we can either configure object storage in workhorse (which uses a native S3 client), or we can configure it in gitlab-rails (which then uses a generic http client in workhorse).

Per https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/295923#note_530773748 , neither of these approaches is currently FIPS-compliant. There does seem to be an easy way to make the former FIPS-compliant - we "just" have to configure the native S3 client to not use MD5 checksums.

We might need to leave the other in place indefinitely, to support object stores that only work with MD5 hashes. I don't know, but do suspect, that self-managed NetApp appliances might fall into this category, for instance.

Ideally, we'd be able to detect when running in FIPS mode and refuse uploads that rely on MD5 functionality in workhorse, to help guide people to FIPS-compliant setups. Unlike Ruby + OpenSSL, the Go implementation of MD5 doesn't raise an error when activated in FIPS mode.

We should also pay attention to the other (non-S3) clients we're using with the workhorse native object store integration. Do they use MD5 similarly?

title: Create `Vulnerability` when interacting with a `Security::Finding` (part 1)
description:
## Why are we doing this work?

After https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/324857 is merged we should make sure to create a new Vulnerability when a user interacts with an unpersisted Finding (ie. goes to MR Security widget, clicks on a found Vulnerability and takes an action on it).

## Implementation plan

- [x] ~backend Update service classes `ee/app/services/vulnerabilities /{resolve,dismiss,revert_to_detected,confirm}_service.rb` to work on Vulnerabilities
- [x] ~backend Add state transition entry for each service 

The following point is moved to https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/368311

* ~backend Modify `Projects::VulnerabilityFeedbackController` to create `Vulnerability` on the fly for a given Finding and use the updated service classes to change it's state
  * This will not create a new feedback object, but only create a vulnerability.
  * We will need to set the `present_on_default_branch` to false for these new vulnerabilities

## Possible follow up items

* Currently our flow for creating issues is different when creating an Issue for a Vulnerability and when creating an Issue for a Vulnerabilities::Finding. The former takes you to the `Create issue` view with the Issue details populated so you can edit it before saving. The latter directly creates the issue without giving the user opportunity to edit the issue.

## Testing

 - [ ] Since this is a significant backend refactor, check if existing E2E tests are broken by running `Package and QA` and checking `Secure` results just before maintainer review

## Verification steps

1. Create a new project under https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/secure/tests
1. ~~Enable feature flag for that project~~ As we removed the FF dependency from these services
1. Go to pipeline security tab/vulnerability report page  
1. Do the interactions (resolve, dismiss, revert_to_detected, confirm) with finding/vulnerability 
1. Make sure nothing is broken and we are creating feedback entires in db for these interactions
1. Also check whether we are creating state transition entires for each of the interaction in db

title: Introduce present_on_default_branch:boolean to Vulnerability model
description:

1. We have more than one source-of-truth for the Vulnerability state
2. It prevents us from building Vulnerability audit trail feature
3. It's unnecessarily complex

See https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/323129 and https://docs.google.com/document/d/1se3qnTH3bOuL9j-A4Kyu_au6eZlzU1zuvGzbOUj_fAw/preview for more details.

## Implementation plan

1. ~database Create a migration that add `present_on_default_branch:boolean` column to `vulnerabilities` table with default value of `true`

title: 🎯 MVC 3 follow-up: Change "Opened" to "Created" within Issues, Epics, and MRs
description:
### Proposal

This issue is a follow up of https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/246959

- [ ] Scope: MVC 3 - files identified in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/246959#note_527962323
- [ ] Address any files that still need to be updated (below)

From @msedlakjakubowski : Some files that I haven't modified in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/56391 because I don't know what they do:

* [app/assets/javascripts/cycle_analytics/components/stage_code_component.vue#L42](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/master/app/assets/javascripts/cycle_analytics/components/stage_code_component.vue#L42)
* [app/assets/javascripts/cycle_analytics/components/stage_component.vue#L42](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/master/app/assets/javascripts/cycle_analytics/components/stage_component.vue#L42)
* [app/assets/javascripts/cycle_analytics/components/stage_review_component.vue#L44](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/master/app/assets/javascripts/cycle_analytics/components/stage_review_component.vue#L44)
* [ee/app/assets/javascripts/analytics/code_review_analytics/components/merge_request_table.vue#L28](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/master/ee/app/assets/javascripts/analytics/code_review_analytics/components/merge_request_table.vue#L28)
* [ee/app/assets/javascripts/analytics/cycle_analytics/components/stage_event_item.vue#L57](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/master/ee/app/assets/javascripts/analytics/cycle_analytics/components/stage_event_item.vue#L57)
* [ee/app/assets/javascripts/issues_analytics/components/issues_analytics.vue](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/master/ee/app/assets/javascripts/issues_analytics/components/issues_analytics.vue) (lines 55, 181, and 187)
* [ee/app/assets/javascripts/issues_analytics/components/issues_analytics_table.vue#L95](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/master/ee/app/assets/javascripts/issues_analytics/components/issues_analytics_table.vue#L95)
* [ee/app/assets/javascripts/related_items_tree/components/tree_item_body.vue#L79](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/master/ee/app/assets/javascripts/related_items_tree/components/tree_item_body.vue#L79)

I've tried changing these two, but I couldn't see where the change was:

* [app/assets/javascripts/issuable_list/constants.js#L14](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/master/app/assets/javascripts/issuable_list/constants.js#L14)
* [app/assets/javascripts/issuable_show/components/issuable_header.vue#L87](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/master/app/assets/javascripts/issuable_show/components/issuable_header.vue#L87)

All the above changes: [created-various.patch](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/uploads/f5a84e16714c63d36c99e2cc7f271a76/created-various.patch)

### Insight

Users are confused by our use of `Opened ## minutes ago` in list views. They assume this indicates when the item was literally "opened up"/visited by another teammate or perhaps updated- and not that this is when the item was created. 



### Supporting evidence
> Interview participant: "This is when the issue was last opened or edited"

Dovetail insight link : https://dovetailapp.com/projects/386754d7-5187-4fe1-8a8d-7f1c3e5d4e2f/insights/present/d1c03566-da2c-4548-93b0-0f41d6d419da

### Action

Change instances of [-Opened-] in lists to [+Created+] within Epics, Issues, and Merge Requests.

| In a list | Within an item |

| ![image](/uploads/8b7097f6f636ccb51b334aa341cf5f4c/image.png)| ![image](/uploads/3465fb2846f941c12fcd2c81b439c9c1/image.png)|

### Tasks
- [x] Assign this issue to the appropriate Product Manager, Product Designer, or UX Researcher.
- [x] Add the appropriate `Group` (such as `~"group::source code"`) label to the issue.  This helps identify and track actionable insights at the group level.

title: Maven sync worker: release xml node missing
description:
### Summary

In https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/55207, a background worker was created to sync the `maven-metadata.xml` file with the versions existing in the database.

Looking at the worker [logs](https://log.gprd.gitlab.net/goto/309b3a50-42fa-11ed-b0ec-930003e0679c), it was revealed that the `<release>` node might be missing.

Update the [`create_versions_xml_service`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/9fce767d4306ac870c4bc088dc7cb61f796f3ec6/app/services/packages/maven/metadata/create_versions_xml_service.rb#L67-77) so that the a non existing `<release>` is accepted.

title: Can't run an on-demand scans in a blank project
description:
When creating a blank project in GitLab, the Git repository is an empty shell without any branch, which makes it impossible to run an on-demand scan, as they need to be associated with a branch. With the recently implemented branch selection feature, this results in an empty ref selector being displayed in the UI, without any options to select from.

This can be seen in the `dast-saved-scans-testing` test project: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/dast-saved-scans-testing/-/on_demand_scans/new

![Screen_Shot_2021-03-16_at_9.53.50_AM](/uploads/8301bd53b3e8e581d1f47e8b1cb342b3/Screen_Shot_2021-03-16_at_9.53.50_AM.png)

What should we do in such case?
* Should we loosen up the restrictions so that a DAST scan can be run without a branch?
* Or block the access to the on-demand scans form altogether as long as no branch exists?
* Something else?

### Proposal

- Show error message, directing user to create a repository in order to run a scan

![select-branch-dropdown-no-branch](/uploads/d2c149f1b7a5e025bb68e7e7bde3061a/select-branch-dropdown-no-branch.png)

### Implementation plan

- [ ] When no default branch is provided to the app, assume that no repository exists and show the error message.

title: [Feature flag] Enable `ci_lower_frequency_trace_update`
description:
<!-- Title suggestion: [Feature flag] Enable description of feature -->

## What

Rollout and then remove `:ci_lower_frequency_trace_update` feature flag.

## Owners

- Team: ~"group::continuous integration" 
- Most appropriate slack channel to reach out to: [`#rapid-action-verify-db-queries`](https://gitlab.slack.com/archives/C01P4L1TND7) and [`#g_ci`](https://gitlab.slack.com/archives/CPCJ8CCCX)
- Best individual to reach out to: @fabiopitino 

## Expectations

### What are we expecting to happen?

This will reduce by half the rate of requests for both `PUT /jobs/:id` and `PATCH /jobs/:id/trace` endpoints that the Runner uses to communicate back to GitLab. The default interval between requests was previously 30 seconds, the feature flag increases it to 60 seconds.

### What might happen if this goes wrong?

We don't expect anything bad to happen since the value is used as is by the Runner to send back the next update of the status or trace.

### What can we monitor to detect problems with this?

Data to monitor: [rate of requests](https://dashboards.gitlab.net/d/api-rails-controller/api-rails-controller?orgId=1&var-PROMETHEUS_DS=Global&var-environment=gprd&var-stage=main&var-controller=Grape&var-action=PATCH%20%2Fapi%2Fjobs%2F:id%2Ftrace&var-action=PUT%20%2Fapi%2Fjobs%2F:id&from=1616655360000&to=1616677019999) of `PUT /jobs/:id` and `PATCH /jobs/:id/trace`


## Beta groups/projects

If applicable, any groups/projects that are happy to have this feature turned on early. Some organizations may wish to test big changes they are interested in with a small subset of users ahead of time for example.

- `gitlab-org/gitlab` project
- `gitlab-org`/`gitlab-com` groups
- ...

## Roll Out Steps

- [x] Enable on staging (`/chatops run feature set feature_name true --staging`)
- [x] Test on staging
- [ ] Ensure that documentation has been updated
- [x] Enable on GitLab.com for individual groups/projects listed above and verify behaviour  (`/chatops run feature set --project=gitlab-org/gitlab feature_name true`)
- [x] Coordinate a time to enable the flag with the SRE oncall and release managers
  - In `#production` mention `@sre-oncall` and `@release-managers`. Once an SRE on call and Release Manager on call confirm, you can proceed with the rollout
- [ ] Announce on the issue an estimated time this will be enabled on GitLab.com
- [x] Enable on GitLab.com by running chatops command in `#production` (`/chatops run feature set feature_name true`)
- [x] Cross post chatops Slack command to `#support_gitlab-com` ([more guidance when this is necessary in the dev docs](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#where-to-run-commands)) and in your team channel
- [x] Announce on the issue that the flag has been enabled
- [ ] Remove feature flag and add changelog entry. Ensure that the feature flag definition YAML file has been removed in the **same MR** that is removing the feature flag from the code
- [ ] After the flag removal is deployed, [clean up the feature flag](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#cleaning-up) by running chatops command in `#production` channel

## Rollback Steps

- [ ] This feature can be disabled by running the following Chatops command:

```
/chatops run feature set --project=gitlab-org/gitlab feature_name false
```

epic.title: The Great Code Review Instrumentation Epic

title: Display error message if the MR Metadata fails to load on the Overview tab
description:
#### Issue

If you have a customized placeholder message (wherein you embed some variables), and the `diffs_metadata.json` fails to load, you'll be left with a commit message that isn't fully hydrated, but **also** you'll have no warning that happened.

#### Proposal

1. 1 failure -> retry (no alert shown)
1. 2 failures -> show alert (and show alert)
   * success: hide alert
1. 3 failures -> stop retrying (keep alert up)

**Alert text:**
> Unable to fully load the default commit message. You can still apply this suggestion and the commit message will be correct.

<details>
<summary>Original issue (follow up from MR)</summary>
The following discussion from !56594 should be addressed:

- [ ] @pedroms continued a [discussion](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/56594#note_529524836):

> @thomasrandolph thank you for the ping. I'm unassigning @sunjungp as she will only “officially” start working in Code Review in the 13.11 milestone.
> 
> If I understand it correctly, this is fetching the necessary data to translate the **suggestion commit message placeholder** when the user is in the `Overview` tab. For this to be used, I think these are the requirements: there must be a valid suggestion and the user must open the `Apply suggestion` dropdown to see the commit message placeholder. Because of these requirements, could we:
> 
> 1. Fail silently on the first failure.
> 1. Try fetching again after a certain delay. Fail silently if this attempt also fails.
> 1. When the user opens the `Apply suggestions` dropdown, try fetching again. If it fails, just display the default commit message with the variables and show a message similar to `Unable to correctly show the default commit message. You can still apply the suggestion.`
> 
> In summary, if we can, let's try our hardest not to show any error messages, unless we really have to :smile:
> 
> @aqualls FYI

----

There are three parts here:

- Error state / failure counter on the network request
- Delayed / "backoff" request retry
- Component-level error display

</details>

title: Use VirtualList to render Swimlanes
description:
To improve performance and the loading experience of Epics Swimlanes, we should use VirtualList component to render epic lanes.

This should be behind a feature flag (`:swimlanes_buffered_rendering`) to help test and turn on/off on gitlab-org where we have a lot of epics.

title: Move defaults into `worker-entry` for a cleaner CI template
description:
### Problem

While reviewing the DAST API template changes it was pointed out that many of the defaults we set could be set in `worker-entry` and removed from the ci templates. This would make for a cleaner template.

### Proposal

1. `_PROFILE`
1. `_CONFIG`
1. `_TIMEOUT`
1. `_REPORT`
1. `_REPORT_ASSET_PATH`
1. `_SERVICE_START_TIMEOUT`

Tasks:

   1. [x] `analyzer-fuzz-api`
1. [x] Update container with proper entrypoint allowing command of `/peach/analyzer-fuzz-api`

title: Default and rename _API variable
description:
### Proposal

The API Security scanner exposes a `_API` variable with the URL to it's instance. As the CI templates are becoming more mature this value can be defaulted to `http://127.0.0.1` in most cases and shouldn't be changed by the user. Also the `_API` variable is confusing to users.

### Proposal

1. [x] Remove variable from CI templates
1. [x] In `worker-entry` default it to `http://127.0.01`.
1. [ ] Rename variable to `_APISECURITY` - `DAST_API_APISECURITY`, `FUZZAPI_APISECURITY`.

title: Add sticky header to group migration table
description:
### Proposal 

We need to add a sticky header to the group import table. By doing so, we keep the user in the context of selecting and initiating a migration without having to scroll from bottom to top in order to move forward. This is especially important when viewing 200 groups per page. 

- The header will stick to the top when you reach its scroll position. 

| Interactions |
| ------ |
| ![05.Sticky_header](/uploads/cae8e742567a218cde296bf18952c7aa/05.Sticky_header.jpg) |

title: Group/project members - migrate to one Vue app and `GlTabs`
description:
## Summary

Follow-up to https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/324675 and https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/324680

Move to one Vue application that uses `GlTabs` to render the "Members", "Groups", "Invited", and "Access requests" tabs. 

## Improvements

Remove deprecated Bootstrap tabs in favor of `GlTabs`

## Risks

Minimal, this is a well tested section of the codebase

## Involved components

- [app/assets/javascripts/members/components/app.vue](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/app/assets/javascripts/members/components/app.vue)
- Create `tab_content.vue`
- Update feature specs as some of them will now need the `:js` tag.
  - [spec/features/projects/members/tabs_spec.rb](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/spec/features/projects/members/tabs_spec.rb)
  - [spec/features/groups/members/tabs_spec.rb](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/spec/features/groups/members/tabs_spec.rb)

## Implementation plan

- Move to one Vue mount point in [app/views/groups/group_members/index.html.haml](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/app/views/groups/group_members/index.html.haml)
- Update [app/assets/javascripts/members/index.js](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/app/assets/javascripts/members/index.js) to accept an object with keys as `MEMBER_TYPE` and value as the options.
```js
{
  [MEMBER_TYPE.user]: {
    tableFields: ['account']
    ...
  },
  [MEMBER_TYPE.group]: {
    tableFields: ['account']
    ...
  }
}
```
- Update Vuex store to have 4 modules, `MEMBER_TYPE.user`, `MEMBER_TYPE.group`, `MEMBER_TYPE.invite`, and `MEMBER_TYPE.accessRequest`
- Create a new `member_tabs.vue` component. This component will render 4 `GlTab` elements with [app/assets/javascripts/members/components/app.vue](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/app/assets/javascripts/members/components/app.vue) in the default slot. It will pass a `namespace` prop to [app/assets/javascripts/members/components/app.vue](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/app/assets/javascripts/members/components/app.vue).
- Update [app/assets/javascripts/members/components/app.vue](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/app/assets/javascripts/members/components/app.vue) to accept a `namespace` prop. Use `provide` to provide the `namespace` prop to all subcomponents.

title: Group/project members - migrate non-reactive state to `provide/inject`
description:
## Summary

There are a number of properties that are currently stored in [app/assets/javascripts/members/store/state.js](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/app/assets/javascripts/members/store/state.js) but are not reactive so do not need to be stored there. As step one in migrating to `GlTabs` we should slim down the number of properties that are stored in the Vuex store so when we move to [Vuex modules](https://vuex.vuejs.org/guide/modules.html#namespacing) only the reactive state will be stored in the namespaced Vuex store. 

This also could provide some performance gains since getters/setters are added to Vuex state and these properties don't need to be reactive.

These are properties that should be converted to `provide/inject`

- `sourceId`
- `currentUserId`
- `canManageMembers`
- `tableFields`
- `tableAttrs`
- `tableSortableFields`
- `memberPath`
- `requestFormatter`
- `filteredSearchBar`

## Improvements

- Make it easier to move towards one Vuex store with multiple namespaced modules
- Performance gains

## Risks

Minimal, this is a well tested section of the codebase

## Involved components

- [app/assets/javascripts/members/store/state.js](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/app/assets/javascripts/members/store/state.js)
- [app/assets/javascripts/members/index.js](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/peterhegman/master/app/assets/javascripts/members/index.js)

- [app/assets/javascripts/members/components/table/members_table.vue](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/app/assets/javascripts/members/components/table/members_table.vue)

title: Group-level VSA - Inconsistent value_stream query parameter
description:
Note: I could only reproduce this locally. On production the `value_stream_id` is set to a number (whereas locally it's set to a string), see:

`https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/analytics/value_stream_analytics?created_after=2021-02-14&created_before=2021-03-15&value_stream_id=779`

vs:

`http://gdk.test:3000/groups/gitlab-org/-/analytics/value_stream_analytics?created_after=2021-02-14&created_before=2021-03-15&value_stream_id=default`

When navigating to the group-level VSA, the FE will automatically append/update URL query parameters. For example, it appends the `value_stream_id` query parameter. When reloading the page, a `404` page is displayed. It seems that the reason for this is that the backend only accepts a `value_stream` query parameter (without the `_id` suffix). We should standardize those query params and make sure there's not difference between FE and BE.

title: BE: Clarify membership via Invited Group
description:
## Summary

In https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/217851/ we introduced the ability to remove users from the root namespace and perpetuate that removal in nested subgroups and projects.

Through the original report (below) we learned that this feature cannot be made available for users who have been invited to a group via an [group invitation](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/group/#share-a-group-with-another-group).

As a result, we should update the Seat usage page to make clear when a billable member was added to the namespace through group invitation. 

## Success Criteria

_Note these tasks can be broken into two issues or multiple MRs on this single issue, deferring to dev_

1. [ ] if a member is invited via group share that prevents removing them, the error message should state that
1. [ ] the seat usage view should highlight membership via shared groups 

## Designs

:white_check_mark:  https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/325411

---

_Retaining original issue description from bug report_

#### Summary

It was reported that attempts to remove a billable member via the **Settings > Billing > See Usage** page does not remove the billable member despite a `user was successfully removed` message.  In the following example, the user in question is listed on the `seat usage` page despite not belonging to any subgroups or projects.

* [Zendesk (Internal)](https://gitlab.zendesk.com/agent/tickets/198880)

#### Steps to reproduce

1. Navigate to the seat usage page and search for a user to remove
2. Use the `Remove User` option to remove the billable member
3. Observe the `user was successfully removed` message
4. Refresh and confirm the user still exists as a billable member

#### Example Project

NOTE: I was unable to replicate this with a test user added to a test project.

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

When a billable member is removed via the Seat Usage page, the billable member remains listed on the seat usage page despite confirmation that it was removed.

#### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

When a billable member is removed via the Seat Usage page, it should no longer be listed on the Seat Usage page and should be removed from all subgroups/projects.

#### Relevant logs and/or screenshots

* [Kibana Logs (Internal)](https://log.gprd.gitlab.net/goto/c9ea85cbbf5078409e1b26a4cb280397)

Note: The logs show an API call to `DELETE` the billable member. However, the member in question remains in both the UI and the [Members API](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/api/members.html#remove-a-billable-member-from-a-group).

#### Output of checks

This bug happens on GitLab.com

#### Availability & Testing

<!-- This section needs to be retained and filled in during the workflow planning breakdown phase of this feature proposal, if not earlier.

What risks does this change pose to our availability? How might it affect the quality of the product? What additional test coverage or changes to tests will be needed? Will it require cross-browser testing?

Please list the test areas (unit, integration and end-to-end) that needs to be added or updated to ensure that this feature will work as intended. Please use the list below as guidance.
* Unit test changes
* Integration test changes
* End-to-end test change

See the test engineering planning process and reach out to your counterpart Software Engineer in Test for assistance: https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/quality/test-engineering/#test-planning -->

Given that this change will likely only be a ~frontend , ~UX change, the only tests that will be required are frontend specs that test the error message(s).  Since this is more of a ~feature gap, I don't see much necessity for an End-to-end test.

If we decide to close this gap in the future, I believe an end-to-end test will be necessary.

title: Ci::AbortPipelinesService should fail jobs
description:
## Problem

[`Ci::AbortPipelinesService`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/56126#note_527961839) currently updates the status of pipelines/stages/jobs to `canceled` in bulk.

[There is a fundamental difference](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/20856#note_523039138) between using `canceled` and `failed + failure_reason`. In case where jobs are dropped by the system we need to use `failed` and communicate the reason to the user through a `failure_reason`.

## Solution

- introduce 2 new failure reasons `:user_blocked` and `:project_deleted` for the 2 cases where the service object is called
- Change `Ci::AbortPipelinesService` to take in input the failure reason and update the statuses to `failed + failure_reason`

title: Parse dependency exports returned by multi-project Java builds (gemnasium-maven)
description:
## Summary

`gemnasium-maven` is currently unaware of multi-project Java builds, and multi-project builds are supported by doing the following:
1. find all supported build files, with no distinction b/w root projects and their sub-projects
1. iterate collected build files, pass each of them to the compatible builder, and make the builder exit right away if there's already a dependency export for the build file

This (mostly) works because:
* building the root project has the side-effect of building its children, and creating dependency exports for them 
* the build file of the root project is processed _before_ the build files of its children, because of the way the project finder walks the scanned directory

`gemnasium-maven` should be changed so that the dependency exports of a multi-project builds are listed when building the root project, instead of recursively finding build files and dependency exports matching these. This would be simpler, and more accurate. Also, it becomes possible to track the name of the sub-project where a dependency was detected.

## Proposal

change `gemnasiumm-maven` so that:
- builders extract the output of the command that builds the root project, and return a list of all the dependency exports it creates
  - Gemnasium Maven plugin
  - Gemnasium Gradle plugin
  - sbt-dependency-graph; see https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/gemnasium-maven/-/merge_requests/107
- all the dependency exports returned by a multi-project build are scanned
- only the root project is found by the `Finder`

## Implementation plan

* [x] change builders in `gemnasium-maven`
   - [x] change the `Builder` interface so that the `Build` function can return the dependency exports for the sub-projects, along with the dependency export for the root project https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/gemnasium-maven/-/merge_requests/107
   - [x] update `sbt` builder: parse output of `sbt` and extract paths of DOT exports https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/gemnasium-maven/-/merge_requests/107
   - [x] change the `Analyze` function so that additional exports returned by the builders are all processed https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/gemnasium-maven/-/merge_requests/107 
   - [x] update `maven` builder: parse output of Gemnasium Maven plugin and extract paths of JSON exports
   - [x] update `gradle` builder: parse output of Gemnasium Gradle plugin and extract paths of JSON exports
   - [x] change `finder` configuration and force the search mode to `SearchSingleDir`; the preset will be updated later on
* ~~simplify `finder`~~; this will be done as part of https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/292952
   - in `gemnasium`, remove [`SearchSingleTree`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/gemnasium/-/blob/v2.29.2/finder/finder.go#L22) mode and change `gemnasium-maven`'s preset to `SearchSingleDir`
   - update `gemnasium` dependency in `gemnasium-maven`, and revert changes to the preset

NOTE: This introduces a discrepancy between the `Builder` defined in gemnasium-maven with the one defined in `gemnasium` and `gemnasium-maven`, but this will be addressed when moving the code of `gemnasium-maven` to `gemnasium`. See https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/292952

## Improvements

- code is simplified, in particular the [finder](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/gemnasium/-/blob/master/finder/finder.go)
- gemnasium-maven and gemnasium-python are further aligned and both use the `finder.SearchSingleDir` search mode
- code is easier to debug; it no longer inspects directories that are not part of the multi-project build

## Risks

- The location of vulnerabilities detected in sub-projects might change, resulting in the loss of vulnerability feedback.
- The `dependency_files[].path` for the sub-projects might change, in the report. This would only change the Dependency List page though.
- Dependencies of the sub-projects might merged into the dependencies of the root project, the `dependency_files` field of the report.
- In case their are multiple root projects in a repo, the new implementation might pick a different one. That said, there are no specs to establish what root project the analyzer should pick and scan.

## Involved components

- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/gemnasium
- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/gemnasium-maven

## Optional: Intended side effects

Sub-projects can be scanned as long as they have a dependency file export, even if there's no build file is detected in the directory of the sub-project. This fixes a bug where Gradle sub-projects are skipped if the build file name isn't `build.gradle`. See https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/322346

## Optional: Missing test coverage

<!--
If you are aware of tests that need to be written or adjusted apart from unit tests for the changed components,
please list them here.
-->

/cc @ifrenkel @gonzoyumo @adamcohen

title: Geo: Verify Snippets (feature parity with Package Files)
description: We implemented verification in Geo for replicated Package Files. This issue is to add verification to Snippets reusing most of that code via the new self-service framework. Do this under feature flag.

title: Build Workhorse once in setup-test-env
description:
I noticed every build stage appears to take 1 minute to build Workhorse:

```
==> Setting up GitLab Workhorse...
    GitLab Workhorse set up in 63.34804652 seconds...
```

Perhaps we need to do what we do with Gitaly and build the binary once?

title: [DevOps Adoption] Pivot GraphQL API from segments to groups
description:
### Problem to solve

DevOps Adoption was originally built with a concept of "segments", but was quickly [pivoted to use the concept of groups](https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/5251).  However, the GraphQL API documentation still [refers to "segments" in 6 places](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/api/graphql/reference/index.html).

### Proposal

Update the GraphQL API's DevOps Adoption aspects to match the feature (pivot segments to groups).

epic.title: Modify DevOps Adoption to focus on groups rather than segments

title: Remember user email from email confirmation link click
description:
# Problem 
Currently, when a user selects to confirm their email address from within the email we send them they are landed on the sign-in page where they have to remember the email/username they signed up with along with their password to sign in. 
  
![image](/uploads/91e041c297583590efc1e1dd35210da3/image.png)
 
# Solution
We should remember their email address in the email confirmation link click and automatically insert the email value into the email/username field. 
 
Note this experience exists for invite emails, we may be able to re use this logic for the email confirmation, here's how the URL is structured when an invited user lands on signin https://gitlab.com/users/sign_in?invite_email= `email_value`

epic.title: Growth Adoption hard email confirmation work

title: Replace `wiki_delete_page` RPC call
description:
At the moment the `Repository` object is able to delete files from the repository using method [delete_file](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/master/app/models/repository.rb#L796).

Wikis use method [delete_page](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/master/app/models/wiki.rb#L196) which is very similar to the `Repository` method, even the signature is very similar.

We can replace the RPC call `wiki_delete_page` with the existing `Repository` method.

epic.title: Wikis should only use the normal repository Gitaly RPCs

title: Rearchitect / Refactor MR Widget [Discovery]
description:
#### What's this issue all about? (Background and context)

[There is a proposal open to rearchitect the MR Widgets mergeability logic](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/300042). Doing so will accomplish many goals, but we need to understand the best path forward technically.

The initial proposal suggests:
- Run mergeability checks one after the other with a success or failure response with details, which may require refactor work
- Different teams own these different checks, empowering code ownership
- Return this object to the frontend to display the errors, versus the method we use today

#### What hypotheses and/or assumptions do you have?

The assumption is that this work can be iterated upon so as to **not** introduce risk and/or breaking changes to the current way we have today. An additional assumption is that the proposal outlined is the best solution, and we are outlining what work that will entail.

#### What questions must be answered?
1. Is the proposal the best solution for the problem? Should work begin on this topic?
1. If this is not the best solution, what is?
1. What technical work will need to happen in order to start iterating? In what order?
1. What are the risks that we need to be aware of if we move forward?

#### What things will you need to investigate during the course of this issue?

- [ ] ...
- [ ] ...

title: Potential: Update ExpireJobCacheWorker to utilize new Sidekiq readonly database replicas capabilities
description:
With the ability to [Allow Sidekiq jobs to use readonly database replicas](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/322452) in place, the next step will be to enable this capability for this worker.

For more context, please check the following links,

- Slides: https://slides.com/nikolamilojevic/deck-eb7ff8/fullscreen
- A recorded Show and Tell introducing Sidekiq Load Balancing, https://youtu.be/PAJ8nvG1AGA
- Documentation(WIP): https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/59397 
- An example of shifting a Sidekiq worker to database replica: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/324377

## Proposal

Use `data_consistency :sticky` because it's the best trade-off. A data consistency `delayed` could cause the job to be rescheduled if the replica hasn't caught up, but the worker is set to run with `urgency :high` so we want to avoid that. A `sticky` mode still allows us to use replica as much as possible.

epic.title: Engineering Allocation: Improve SaaS Reliability in the Verify stage

- An example of shifting a Sidekiq worker to database replica: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/324377
  - https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/57575

### Proposal 

We should probably use `:sticky` here since this is a high urgency job.

https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/59397/diffs#b9836038e260c04acaf1e719b7b37d1b29abedcf_459_473

It's not idempotent, so it should be easier to switch to `:sticky`.
